rows.name: Looking into a topic – e.g. Subitizing

name.eng: Looking into a topic – e.g. Subitizing

block1_text.eng: This example explores learning about a subject or topic area. We will use "subitizing" as our example. There are at least four ways to learn more about it in this app.

block2_text.eng:
Navigate to this topic:
* On the Home Page, press the Topics button. 
* Looking at the high level strands, you decide to explore "Number & Place Value." 
* Within that, subitizing usually involves moderately small quantities, so you select "Quantities and Counting to 10." 
* Here you spot the button for the topic "Subitizing to 10."

On this Topic page you will find discussions of the importantance of subitizing, its relationship to unitizing, beginning standard dot arrangements to use, the use of ten frames, and its link to Counting On. There is also a tip about five frames being not so useful for subitizing. 

At the bottom of this topic page, as there is at the bottom of most topic pages, you will find:
* A pull down list of Related Topics. At the moment, this displays 2 topics that come before this topic, and 5 topics that are natural next steps.
* A link to the Resource Finder. This will search for resources related to subitizing. At the moment it finds 1 game and 5 routines.
* A link to the Glossary. In this case, it highlights glossary entries for Counting On, Subitizing, and Ten Frames.

block3_text.eng:
This is not functional for now. When it does work, it will be a similar experience to using "Topics." 

For now, you can navigate to the topic you are interested in and click the "Resources" button at the bottom of the page.

block4_text.eng:
Navigate to the Glossary:
* On the Home Page, press the Resources button. 
* Next, select the "Glossary" button to get to the list of terms in the glossary. 
* Scroll down to find the entry for "subitizing." 

This entry has a short description of the term along with some comments about it. 

From this entry you can select "Related Topics" to find further information about it.

block5_text.eng:
Maybe you've seen a Dot Card or a Splat Card and want to learn more about those routines or find others like them. 

Navigate to the Resources:
* On the Home Page, press the Resources button.
* Next, select the "Routines" button.

Describe finding some routines ...

rows.name: You want a quick Routine

block1_text.eng:
Suppose you have a short period of time, say 1 to 10 minutes, that you want to fill with an activity.

**A quick playful activity** The games for breaks option is a good fit for this.

Navigate to these games:
* Select the Resources button on the Home Page
* Select the Games button on the Resources Page
* On the Games Page, turn off (slide left) the slider for "All" and turn on (slide right) the slider for "Breaks." Select the levels that are appropriate for your class.

**A quick math lesson** The Routines section is designed to have resources for this situation. 

Navigate to Routines:
* Select the Resources button on the Home Page
* Select the Routines button on the Resources Page

The Resources section is broken up into resources by math skill level.

rows.name: You want a Rich Task

block1_text.eng:
Rich Tasks involve a deeper dive into a math question or subject. Some of them can be done in a single lesson, but many can be extended into several lessons as you follow the students' interests and questions.

Navigate to Rich Tasks:
* Select the Resources button on the Home Page
* Select the Rich Tasks button on the Resources Page

The Rich tasks come in two types – Open-Ended Tasks and Problem Solving Tasks.
